quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.text: When we communicate, especially spontaneously, we want to do it really well. We want to answer the question with the best answer, we want to give the right feedback, we want to be the most interesting in small talk and that puts a lot of pressure on ourselves.

quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.text: Your brain in many ways is like a CPU, a computer. If I am constantly judging and evaluating everything I am saying against some standard of perfection, it means I have a limited amount of bandwidth to focus on what I'm actually saying and connecting to my audience.

quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.text: How we label the arousal matters. When we feel those symptoms of anxiety, rather than seeing it as negative, say, 'This is exciting. I get to share my point of view. I get to demonstrate my value.' And in so doing by seeing it as more positive, it causes us by definition to relax.

quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.text: You actually have to prepare to be spontaneous. And that's counterintuitive, but when you think about it in athletics or jazz music, it's like of course you would prepare and practice.

quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.text: Structure is nothing more than a beginning, a middle, and an end. A package of information. By finding a structure that you can rely on when put on the spot, it halves your burden. When you're put on the spot, you have to think about what to say and how to say it. The structure tells you how to say it, and then you just have to think about what to put into it.

quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.text: What is your product, your service, your offering, your update, your feedback? It's the what of why you're speaking. The so what is why is this important and relevant to the people you're talking to. And then the now what is what comes next.

quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.text: The only way you get better at communication, spontaneous or planned, is the way you get better at anything. Repetition, reflection, and feedback. You got to practice, you got to think about what worked or what didn't, and then you have to get feedback from others. We are not always the best judges of our communication.

quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.text: Be interested, not interesting. Many of us go into small talk thinking we have to be super interesting. We have to spike the ball over the net every time. When in fact small talk is more like playing the game of Hacky Sack, where it's simply just set the other person up to be successful and get the ball back to you.

quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.text: Feedback to me is an opportunity to problem solve. It's not me bestowing upon you my opinion, it's me inviting you to together work on whatever this issue challenge is that we have.

quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.text: Nobody has ever complained about a toast that's too brief. The majority of complaints are the toast went on forever.

quotes.speaker: Matt Abrahams
quotes.text: I believe in minimally viable communication, where it's the same principles. Know your audience, put together a rough draft of what you want to say, test it out. If you're going to give a big toast in front of a company all hands, run it by a few people. We are not the best judges of our communication.

takeaways: Strive for connection over perfection by 'daring to be dull' -- lowering self-evaluation pressure frees cognitive bandwidth to actually communicate better.
Use structures like 'What? So What? Now What?' to halve your burden when speaking spontaneously -- the structure handles the 'how' so you only think about the 'what.'
Reframe anxiety as excitement -- the physiological response is identical, and relabeling it positively causes you to relax and communicate better.
Be interested, not interesting in conversations -- small talk is like hacky sack, not volleyball; set others up and match disclosure levels.
Treat feedback as collaborative problem-solving, not judgment delivery -- use structures like the 4 I's (Information, Impact, Invitation, Implications) to package difficult conversations.

contrarian_candidates.why: The idea that spontaneity requires preparation is counterintuitive -- most people assume being spontaneous means not preparing.
Applying MVP thinking to communication challenges the notion that great communicators are simply naturally gifted.
